I'm a medical doctor so this piqued my curiosity, and indeed it's a very rare and interesting case.

I'd just like to point out that at 1:46 the statement "His CD4 count was 28 per cubic millimeter where below 200 indicates SEVERE INFECTION" ("severe infection" in boldface) is ambiguous. It's correct if we're talking about HIV infection (i.e. AIDS), but people can be confused in thinking that the "infection" in the statement pertains to infection(s) of organisms like bacteria, viruses, parasites, etc. that's obviously a common occurrence in AIDS. It would have been better to say "severe HIV infection" AND then state that a count < 200 is a critical juncture wherein opportunistic infections start to increase significantly because the immune system is impaired. For example, infections with Pneumocystis jirovecii, which causes pneumonia, rises sharply and is the reason why patients with AIDS take TMP/SMX (an antibiotic) as prophylaxis when their CD4 count drops below 200.

As a med student this makes me think of how many diseases go misdiagnosed. This rare case was identified because the doctors involved took notice of how the ‘cancer cells’ are oddly smaller and they had the tools to thoroughly examine the cellular DNA which later revealed to be tapeworm canceroid cells.
But in many cases I know that either (1) doctors would just write them off as atypically small cancer cells and/or (2) the hospital wouldn’t have the facilities for any further examination.
I hope in the future we could improve our diagnostic approach and hospitals/institutions with their tools.

Very nice and interesting video. I just wanted to make two corrections, one science-based and the other about terms (not very important regarding the message and explanation of the video though).

The first one and least important is "doctors and pathologists which are the scientists that study diseases", while true it implies that pathologists are not doctors which they are (a bit picky on my part to be honest xD).

The other one is about "cytokeratin and vimentin expressed in cancer cells" it's a bit of an oversimplification, which I suppose is necessary to summarise. Still, to be precise these proteins are used more for cell lineage markers. So cytokeratins (of which there are more than 20 different types) are used to identify epithelial cells; all epithelial cells in the body express some sort of cytokeratin and, usually, carcinomas (although not all) which come from epithelium tend to express them. Vimentin for the other part is more inespecific but generally is used to identify mesenquimal cells and the tumors derived from them, so sarcomas. It is a bit of a simplification because there are sarcomas that don't express vimentin and some express cytokeratins and there are carcinomas that express vimentin and not keratins, but as a rule of thumb keratin for epithelial cells (also carcinomas) and vimentin for mesenquimal cells (also sarcomas). To further complicate matters there are neoplasma that are not epithelial nor mesenquimal such as lymphomas or melanomas. Luckily we have a huge array of markers to try to identify them.

I have a rare disease (IIH - Intracranial Idiopathic Hypertension, it has less than 200,000 cases in the U.S. per year) and I truly hope my case can help with people who’ll get it in the future. They don’t even know what causes it yet. They know how to treat it and what the risk factors can be, but other than that, they have no clue. They only have guesses on what causes it at this point.

“IIH happens when too much cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) — the fluid around the brain and spinal cord — builds up in your skull. This puts extra pressure on your brain and on the nerve in the back of your eye, called the optic nerve.” - from the National Eye Institute.

But what causes the buildup of the fluid? Nobody knows for sure.

In 2013, a 41-year-old Colombian man was diagnosed with the rarest cancer ever seen—malignant masses of cells from a tapeworm. It took five months for doctors in Colombia and researchers in the U.S. to figure out what was going on. The clumps of cells look like stem cells, which are able to keep growing and dividing just like cancer cells, but are smaller and less organized. They also have large nuclei, which is common in stem cells and points to something malignant. A DNA test for amoebas, slime molds, and fungi turned up a surprising match-it's actually tapeworm DNA. Researchers don't expect this to be a common result of an HIV infection, but it could lead doctors to look more closely at cancer-like clumps.

There is a characteristic known to (often zoonotic) parasites, called larval migrans. In general terms, this may happen when a parasite is not perfectly suited to its host and the larvae, in an attempt to find the proper environment, begin 'swimming' through the body's tissues, looking for their home (Toxocara canis); it is also a typical behavior of other types of parasites (trichinosis).

Although this hookworm seems perfectly adapted to humans, I wonder if an atavistic 'larval migration capability' was triggered by the unusual immune environment. This would answer the question 'how did these cells physically travel from the intestine to various other places in the patient's body'.
